[The deck]517-the deck was deserted , and [he]250-harvey crawled to the extreme end of [it]517-the deck , near the flag - pole . There [he]250-harvey doubled up in limp agony , for the Wheeling ' stogie " joined with the surge and jar of the screw to sieve out [his]250-harvey soul . [His]250-harvey head swelled ; sparks of fire danced before [his]250-harvey eyes ; [his]250-harvey body seemed to lose weight , while [his]250-harvey heels wavered in the breeze . [He]250-harvey was fainting from seasickness , and a roll of [the ship]1851-the ship tilted [him]250-harvey over the rail on to the smooth lip of the turtle - back . Then [a low , gray mother]1852-a low , gray mother - wave swung out of the fog , tucked [Harvey]250-harvey under one arm , so to speak , and pulled [him]250-harvey off and away to leeward ; the great green closed over [him]250-harvey , and [he]250-harvey went quietly to sleep . [He]250-harvey was roused by the sound of a dinner - horn such as they used to blow at [a summer - school [he]250-harvey had once attended in [the Adirondacks]18-the adirondacks]1853-a summer - school he had once attended in the adirondacks . Slowly [he]250-harvey remembered that [he]250-harvey was [Harvey Cheyne]250-harvey , drowned and dead in [mid - ocean]1854-mid - ocean , but was too weak to fit things together . A new smell filled [his]250-harvey nostrils ; wet and clammy chills ran down [his]250-harvey back , and [he]250-harvey was helplessly full of salt water . When [he]250-harvey opened [his]250-harvey eyes , [he]250-harvey perceived that [he]250-harvey was still on the top of [the sea]1855-the sea , for it was running round [him]250-harvey in silver - coloured hills , and [he]250-harvey was lying on a pile of half - dead fish , looking at a broad human back clothed in a blue jersey . [I]250-harvey live to [Gloucester]19-gloucester . By - and - by [we]1862-we get supper . Eh , wha - at ? "[250-harvey] [He]250-harvey seemed to have two pairs of hands and a head of cast - iron , for , not content with blowing through a big conch - shell , [he]250-harvey must needs stand up to it , swaying with the sway of the flat - bottomed dory , and send a grinding , thuttering shriek through the fog . How long this entertainment lasted , [Harvey]250-harvey could not remember , for [he]250-harvey lay back terrified at the sight of the smoking swells . [He]250-harvey fancied [he]250-harvey heard a gun and a horn and shouting . Something bigger than [the dory]520-the dory , but quite as lively , loomed alongside . Several voices talked at once ; [he]250-harvey was dropped into a dark , heaving hole , where [men in oilskins]521-men in oilskins gave [him]250-harvey a hot drink and took off [his]250-harvey clothes , and [he]250-harvey fell asleep . When [he]250-harvey waked [he]250-harvey listened for the first breakfast - bell on [the steamer]522-the steamer , wondering why [[his]250-harvey state - room]523-his state - room had grown so small . Turning , [he]250-harvey looked into [a narrow , triangular cave , lit by a lamp hung against a huge square beam]524-a narrow , triangular cave , lit by a lamp hung against a huge square beam . A three - cornered table within arm 's reach ran from the angle of the bows to the foremast . At the after end , behind a well - used Plymouth stove , sat [a boy about [his]525-a boy about his own age own age]525-a boy about his own age , with [a flat red face and a pair of twinkling gray eyes]526-a flat red face and a pair of twinkling gray eyes . [He]525-a boy about his own age was dressed in a blue jersey and high rubber boots . Several pairs of the same sort of foot - wear , an old cap , and some worn - out woollen socks lay on the floor , and black and yellow oilskins swayed to and fro beside the bunks . [The place]527-the place was packed as full of smells as a bale is of cotton . The oilskins had a peculiarly thick flavor of their own which made a sort of background to the smells of fried fish , burnt grease , paint , pepper , and stale tobacco ; but these , again , were all hooped together by one encircling smell of ship and salt water . [Harvey]250-harvey saw with disgust that there were no sheets on [his]250-harvey bed - place . [He]250-harvey was lying on a piece of dingy ticking full of lumps and nubbles . Then , too , [the boat]528-the boat 's motion was not that of [a steamer]529-a steamer . [She]530-she was neither sliding nor rolling , but rather wriggling [herself]530-she about in a silly , aimless way , like [a colt at the end of a halter]531-a colt at the end of a halter . Water - noises ran by close to [his]250-harvey ear , and beams creaked and whined about [him]250-harvey . All these things made [him]250-harvey grunt despairingly and think of [[his]250-harvey mother]1807-his mother . " Feelin ' better ? "[1817-the boy] said [the boy]1817-the boy , with a grin . " [Hev]250-harvey some coffee ? "[1817-the boy] [He]1817-the boy brought a tin cup full and sweetened it with molasses . " Is n't there milk ? "[250-harvey] said [Harvey]250-harvey , looking round the dark double tier of bunks as if [he]250-harvey expected to find a cow there . " Well , no , "[1817-the boy] said [the boy]1817-the boy . " Ner there ai n't likely to be till ' baout mid - September . ' Tain't bad coffee . [I]1817-the boy made it . "[1817-the boy] [Harvey]250-harvey drank in silence , and [the boy]1817-the boy handed [him]250-harvey a plate full of pieces of crisp fried pork , which [he]250-harvey ate ravenously . " [I]1817-the boy 've dried [your]250-harvey clothes . Guess [they]1864-they 've shrunk some , "[1817-the boy] said [the boy]1817-the boy . " [They]1864-they ai n't [our]1865-our style much - none of 'em . Twist round an ' see if [you]250-harvey 're hurt any . "[1817-the boy] [Harvey]250-harvey stretched [himself]250-harvey in every direction , but could not report any injuries . " That 's good , "[1817-the boy] [the boy]1817-the boy said heartily . " Fix yerself an ' go on [deck]1866-deck . [Dad]259-dad wants to see [you]250-harvey . [I]1817-the boy 'm [[his]259-dad son]1867-his son , - [Dan]260-dan , [they]1864-they call [me]1817-the boy , - an ' [I]1817-the boy 'm cook 's helper an ' everything else aboard that 's too dirty for [the men]1868-the men . There ai n't [no boy]1869-no boy here ' cep ' [me]1817-the boy sence [Otto]261-otto went overboard - an ' [he]261-otto was only [a Dutchy]1870-a dutchy , an ' twenty year old at that . How 'd [you]250-harvey come to fall off in [a dead flat ca'am]1871-a dead flat ca'am ? "[1817-the boy] " ' Twasn't a calm , "[250-harvey] said [Harvey]250-harvey , sulkily . " It was a gale , and [I]250-harvey was seasick . Guess [I]250-harvey must have rolled over the rail . "[250-harvey] " There was a little common swell yes'day an ' last night , "[1817-the boy] said [the boy]1817-the boy . " But ef thet 's [your]250-harvey notion of a gale - - "[250-harvey] [He]250-harvey whistled . " [You]250-harvey 'll know more ' fore [you]250-harvey 're through . Hurry ! [Dad]259-dad 's waitin ' . "[250-harvey] Like [many other unfortunate young people]539-many other unfortunate young people , [Harvey]250-harvey had never in all [his]250-harvey life received a direct order - never , at least , without long , and sometimes tearful , explanations of the advantages of obedience and the reasons for the request . [Mrs. Cheyne]262-cheyne lived in fear of breaking [his]250-harvey spirit , which , perhaps , was the reason that [she]262-cheyne [herself]262-cheyne walked on the edge of nervous prostration . [He]250-harvey could not see why [he]250-harvey should be expected to hurry for [any man]540-any man 's pleasure , and said so . " [[Your]260-dan dad]1872-your dad can come down here if [he]1872-your dad 's so anxious to talk to [me]260-dan . [I]260-dan want [him]1872-your dad to take [me]260-dan to [New York]8-new york right away . It 'll pay [him]1872-your dad . "[260-dan] [Dan]260-dan opened [his]260-dan eyes as the size and beauty of this joke dawned on [him]260-dan . " Say , [Dad]259-dad ! "[260-dan] [he]260-dan shouted up the foc'sle hatch , " [he]1872-your dad says [you]260-dan kin slip down an ' see [him]1872-your dad ef [you]260-dan 're anxious that way . ' Hear , [Dad]259-dad ? "[260-dan] The answer came back in the deepest voice [Harvey]250-harvey had ever heard from [a human chest]541-a human chest : " Quit foolin ' , [Dan]260-dan , and send [him]1872-your dad to [me]260-dan . "[260-dan] [Dan]260-dan sniggered , and threw [Harvey]250-harvey [his]250-harvey warped bicycle shoes . There was something in the tones on [the deck]517-the deck that made [the boy]1817-the boy dissemble [his]1817-the boy extreme rage and console [himself]1817-the boy with the thought of gradually unfolding the tale of [his]1817-the boy own and [[his]1817-the boy father]1810-his father 's wealth on the voyage [home]545-home . This rescue would certainly make [him]1817-the boy [a hero among [[his]1817-the boy friends]547-his friends for life]546-a hero among his friends for life . [He]250-harvey hoisted [himself]250-harvey on deck up a perpendicular ladder , and stumbled aft , over a score of obstructions , to where [a small , thick - set , clean - shaven man with gray eyebrows]548-a small , thick - set , clean - shaven man with gray eyebrows sat on a step that led up to [the quarter - deck]549-the quarter - deck . The swell had passed in the night , leaving [a long , oily sea]550-a long , oily sea , dotted round the horizon with the sails of [a dozen fishing - boats]551-a dozen fishing - boats . Between [them]551-a dozen fishing - boats lay little black specks , showing where [the dories]552-the dories were out fishing . [The schooner]553-the schooner , with a triangular riding - sail on the mainmast , played easily at anchor , and except for [the man by the cabin - roof]554-the man by the cabin - roof - " house "[555-they] [they]555-they call [it]556-it - [she]553-the schooner was deserted . " Mornin ' - Good afternoon , [I]555-they should say . [You]250-harvey 've nigh slep ' the clock round , [young feller]1873-young feller , "[555-they] was the greeting . [He]250-harvey did not like being called " [young feller]1873-young feller "[250-harvey] ; and , as [one rescued from drowning]557-one rescued from drowning , expected sympathy . " Naow let 's hear all abaout it . It 's quite providential , first an ' last , fer all concerned . What might be [your]250-harvey name ? Where from [we]1875-we mistrust it 's Noo [York]20-york , an ' where baound [we]1875-we mistrust it 's [Europe]9-europe ? "[250-harvey] [Harvey]250-harvey gave [his]250-harvey name , the name of [the steamer]522-the steamer , and a short history of the accident , winding up with a demand to be taken back immediately to [New York]8-new york , where [[his]250-harvey father]1810-his father would pay anything [any one]562-any one chose to name . "[250-harvey] [Troop]260-dan went down solemnly into [the cabin]569-the cabin , where [he]260-dan and [the older men]570-the older men bunked , leaving [Dan]260-dan to comfort [the luckless heir]571-the luckless heir to thirty millions . CHAPTER II " [I]260-dan warned [ye]250-harvey , "[260-dan] said [Dan]260-dan , as the drops fell thick and fast on the dark , oiled planking . " [Dad]259-dad ai n't noways hasty , but [you]250-harvey fair earned it . [Pshaw]249-pshaw ! there 's no sense takin ' on so . "[260-dan] [Harvey]250-harvey 's shoulders were rising and falling in spasms of dry sobbing . " [I]260-dan know the feelin ' . "[260-dan] shouted [Dan]260-dan , and [Harvey]250-harvey pulled , astonished to find how easily the dory rose . "[272-manuel] " [I]250-harvey 'm - [I]250-harvey 'm ever so grateful , "[250-harvey] [Harvey]250-harvey stammered , and [his]250-harvey unfortunate hand stole to [his]250-harvey pocket once more , but [he]250-harvey remembered that [he]250-harvey had no money to offer . When [he]250-harvey knew [Manuel]272-manuel better the mere thought of the mistake [he]250-harvey might have made would cover [him]250-harvey with hot , uneasy blushes in [his]250-harvey bunk . " "[288-fife] [Frenchman of Anguille]289-frenchman of anguille . " "[289-frenchman of anguille] Ah ! [Them]645-them [West Shore]43-west shore [Frenchmen]646-frenchmen do n't caount anyway . Stands to reason [they]645-them ca n't caount Ef [you]0-i run acrost any of [their]645-them soft hooks , [Harvey]250-harvey , [you]0-i 'll know why , " said [Dan]260-dan , with an awful contempt . "[250-harvey] Always more and never less , Every time [we]647-we come to dress , " [Long Jack]273-long jack roared down the hatch , and the ' second ha'af "[250-harvey] scrambled up at once . The shadow of the masts and rigging , with the never - furled riding - sail , rolled to and fro on the heaving deck in the moonlight ; and the pile of fish by the stern shone like a dump of fluid silver . In [the hold]648-the hold there were tramplings and rumblings where [Disko Troop]263-disko and [Tom Platt]274-tom platt moved among the salt - bins . [Dan]260-dan passed [Harvey]250-harvey a pitchfork , and led [him]250-harvey to the inboard end of the rough table , where [Uncle Salters]276-uncle salters was drumming impatiently with a knife - haft . A tub of salt water lay at [his]250-harvey feet . " [You]260-dan pitch to [Dan]260-dan an ' [Tom Platt]274-tom platt down the hatch , an ' take [keer Uncle Salters]276-uncle salters do n't cut [yer]260-dan eye out , "[260-dan] said [Dan]260-dan , swinging [himself]260-dan into the hold . " [I]260-dan 'll pass salt below . "[260-dan] [Penn]284-penn and [Manuel]272-manuel stood knee deep among cod in the pen , flourishing drawn knives . [Long Jack]273-long jack , a basket at [his]273-long jack feet and mittens on [his]273-long jack hands , faced [Uncle Salters]276-uncle salters at the table , and [Harvey]250-harvey stared at the pitchfork and the tub . " Hi ! "[272-manuel] shouted [Manuel]272-manuel , stooping to the fish , and bringing one up with a finger under its gill and a finger in its eyes . [He]272-manuel laid it on the edge of the pen ; the knife - blade glimmered with a sound of tearing , and the fish , slit from throat to vent , with a nick on either side of the neck , dropped at [Long Jack]273-long jack 's feet . " Hi ! "[273-long jack] said [Long Jack]273-long jack , with a scoop of [his]273-long jack mittened hand . The cod 's liver dropped in the basket . Another wrench and scoop sent the head and offal flying , and the empty fish slid across to [Uncle Salters]276-uncle salters , who snorted fiercely . There was another sound of tearing , the backbone flew over the bulwarks , and the fish , headless , gutted , and open , splashed in the tub , sending the salt water into [Harvey]250-harvey 's astonished mouth . After the first yell , [the men]1868-the men were silent . The cod moved along as though [they]1868-the men were alive , and long ere [Harvey]250-harvey had ceased wondering at the miraculous dexterity of it all , [his]250-harvey tub was full . " Pitch ! "[276-uncle salters] grunted [Uncle Salters]276-uncle salters , without turning [his]276-uncle salters head , and [Harvey]250-harvey pitched the fish by twos and threes down the hatch . " Hi ! Pitch 'em bunchy , "[260-dan] shouted [Dan]260-dan . " Do n't scatter ! [Uncle Salters]276-uncle salters is [the best splitter in the fleet]2069-the best splitter in the fleet . Watch [him]276-uncle salters mind [his]276-uncle salters book ! "[260-dan] Indeed , it looked a little as though [the round uncle]650-the round uncle were cutting magazine pages against time . [Manuel]272-manuel 's body , cramped over from the hips , stayed like a statue ; but [his]272-manuel long arms grabbed the fish without ceasing . [Little Penn]284-penn toiled valiantly , but it was easy to see [he]284-penn was weak . Once or twice [Manuel]272-manuel found time to help [him]284-penn without breaking the chain of supplies , and once [Manuel]272-manuel howled because [he]272-manuel had caught [his]272-manuel finger in a Frenchman 's hook . These hooks are made of soft metal , to be rebent after use ; but the cod very often get away with them and are hooked again elsewhere ; and that is one of the many reasons why [the Gloucester boats]651-the gloucester boats despise [the Frenchmen]652-the frenchmen . Down below , the rasping sound of rough salt rubbed on rough flesh sounded like the whirring of a grindstone - steady undertune to the " click - nick "[276-uncle salters] of knives in the pen ; the wrench and shloop of torn heads , dropped liver , and flying offal ; the " caraaah "[276-uncle salters] of [Uncle Salters]276-uncle salters 's knife scooping away backbones ; and the flap of wet , open bodies falling into the tub . At the end of an hour [Harvey]250-harvey would have given [the world]653-the world to rest ; for fresh , wet cod weigh more than [you]654-you would think , and [his]250-harvey back ached with the steady pitching . But [he]250-harvey felt for the first time in [his]250-harvey life that [he]250-harvey was [one of [the working gang of men]656-the working gang of men]655-one of the working gang of men , took pride in the thought , and held on sullenly . " Knife oh ! "[276-uncle salters] shouted [Uncle Salters]276-uncle salters at last . [Penn]284-penn doubled up , gasping among the fish , [Manuel]272-manuel bowed back and forth to supple [himself]272-manuel , and [Long Jack]273-long jack leaned over [the bulwarks]657-the bulwarks . [The cook]628-the cook appeared , noiseless as a black shadow , collected a mass of backbones and heads , and retreated . " Blood - ends for breakfast an ' head - chowder , "[273-long jack] said [Long Jack]273-long jack , smacking [his]273-long jack lips . " Knife oh ! "[276-uncle salters] repeated [Uncle Salters]276-uncle salters , waving the flat , curved splitter 's weapon . " Look by [your]260-dan foot , [Harve]250-harvey , "[260-dan] cried [Dan]260-dan below . [Harvey]250-harvey saw half a dozen knives stuck in a cleat in the hatch combing . [He]250-harvey dealt these around , taking over the dulled ones . " Water ! "[263-disko] said [Disko Troop]263-disko . " Scuttle - butt 's for'ard an ' the dipper 's alongside . Hurry , Harve , "[260-dan] said [Dan]260-dan . [He]260-dan was back in a minute with a big dipperful of stale brown water which tasted like nectar , and loosed the jaws of [Disko]263-disko and [Tom Platt]274-tom platt . " These are cod , "[263-disko] said [Disko]263-disko . " [They]2070-they ai n't Damarskus figs , [Tom Platt]274-tom platt , nor yet silver bars . [I]263-disko 've told [you]274-tom platt that ever single time since [we]2071-we 've sailed together . "[263-disko] " A matter o ' seven seasons , "[274-tom platt] returned [Tom Platt]274-tom platt coolly . " Good stowin 's good stowin ' all the same , an ' there 's a right an ' a wrong way o ' stowin ' ballast even . If [you]274-tom platt 'd ever seen four hundred ton o ' iron set into the - "[274-tom platt] " Hi ! "[272-manuel] With a yell from [Manuel]272-manuel the work began again , and never stopped till the pen was empty . The instant the last fish was down , [Disko Troop]263-disko rolled aft to [the cabin]569-the cabin with [[his]263-disko brother]2060-his brother ; [Manuel]272-manuel and [Long Jack]273-long jack went forward ; [Tom Platt]274-tom platt only waited long enough to slide home the hatch ere [he]274-tom platt too disappeared . In half a minute [Harvey]250-harvey heard deep snores in [the cabin]569-the cabin , and [he]250-harvey was staring blankly at [Dan]260-dan and [Penn]284-penn . " [I]284-penn did a little better that time , [Danny]260-dan , "[284-penn] said [Penn]284-penn , whose eyelids were heavy with sleep . " But [I]284-penn think it is [my]284-penn duty to help clean . "[284-penn] " ' Would n't [hev]2072-hev [your]250-harvey conscience fer a thousand quintal , "[260-dan] said [Dan]260-dan . " Turn in , [Penn]284-penn . [You]250-harvey 've no call to do [boy]2073-boy 's work . Draw a bucket , [Harvey]250-harvey . Oh , [Penn]284-penn , dump these in the gurry - butt ' fore [you]250-harvey sleep . Kin [you]250-harvey keep awake that long ? "[284-penn] [Penn]284-penn took up the heavy basket of fish - livers , emptied them into a cask with a hinged top lashed by the foc'sle ; then [he]284-penn too dropped out of sight in [the cabin]569-the cabin . " [Boys]2074-boys clean up after dressin ' down an ' first watch in ca'am weather is [boy]2073-boy 's watch on the ' [We]2076-we 're Here ' . "[260-dan] [Dan]260-dan sluiced the pen energetically , unshipped the table , set it up to dry in the moonlight , ran the red knife - blades through a wad of oakum , and began to sharpen them on a tiny grindstone , as [Harvey]250-harvey threw offal and backbones overboard under [his]250-harvey direction . At the first splash a silvery - white ghost rose bolt upright from [the oily water]663-the oily water and sighed a weird whistling sigh . [Harvey]250-harvey started back with a shout , but [Dan]260-dan only laughed . " [Grampus]290-grampus , "[250-harvey] said [he]250-harvey . " Beggin ' fer fish - heads . [They]2074-boys up - eend the way when [they]2074-boys 're hungry . Breath on [him]2074-boys like [the doleful tombs]2077-the doleful tombs , hain't [he]2074-boys ? "[250-harvey] A horrible stench of decayed fish filled the air as the pillar of white sank , and the water bubbled oilily . " Hain't [ye]250-harvey never seen a grampus up - eend before ? [You]250-harvey 'll see ['em]2078-'em by hundreds ' fore [ye're]250-harvey through . Say , it 's good to [hev]2074-boys [a boy]2079-a boy aboard again . [Otto]261-otto was too old , an ' [a Dutchy]1870-a dutchy at that . [Him]261-otto an ' [me]664-the moon [we]2081-we fought consid'ble . ' Would n't [ha]2082-ha ' keered fer that ef [he]2074-boys 'd [he]2074-boys d a Christian tongue in [his]2074-boys head . [Sleepy]291-sleepy ? "[664-the moon] " Dead sleepy , "[250-harvey] said [Harvey]250-harvey , nodding forward . " Must n't sleep on watch . [Rouse]292-rouse up an ' see ef [our]2081-we anchor - light 's bright an ' shinin ' . [You]250-harvey 're on watch now , [Harve]250-harvey . "[250-harvey] " [Pshaw]249-pshaw ! What 's to hurt [us]2081-we ? Bright 's day . Sn - orrr ! "[664-the moon] " Jest when things happen , [Dad]259-dad says . Fine weather 's good sleepin ' , an ' ' fore [you]250-harvey know , [mebbe]2083-mebbe , [you]250-harvey 're cut in two by [a liner]2084-a liner , an ' [seventeen brass - bound officers]2085-seventeen brass - bound officers , [all gen'elmen]2086-all gen'elmen , lift [their]2085-seventeen brass - bound officers hand to it that [your]250-harvey lights was aout an ' there was a thick fog . [Harve]250-harvey , [I]664-the moon 've kinder took to [you]250-harvey , but ef [you]250-harvey nod onet more [I]664-the moon 'll lay into [you]250-harvey with a rope 's end . "[664-the moon] [The moon]664-the moon , who sees many strange things on [the Banks]44-the banks , looked down on [a slim youth in knickerbockers and a red jersey , staggering around the cluttered decks of [a seventy - ton schooner]666-a seventy - ton schooner]665-a slim youth in knickerbockers and a red jersey , staggering around the cluttered decks of a seventy - ton schooner , while behind [him]664-the moon , waving a knotted rope , walked , after the manner of [an executioner]667-an executioner , [a boy who yawned and nodded between the blows]668-a boy who yawned and nodded between the blows [he]664-the moon dealt . The lashed wheel groaned and kicked softly , the riding - sail slatted a little in the shifts of the light wind , the windlass creaked , and the miserable procession continued . [Harvey]250-harvey expostulated , threatened , whimpered , and at last wept outright , while [Dan]260-dan , the words clotting on [his]260-dan tongue , spoke of the beauty of watchfulness and slashed away with the rope 's end , punishing the dories as often as [he]260-dan hit [Harvey]250-harvey . At last the clock in [the cabin]569-the cabin struck ten , and upon the tenth stroke [little Penn]284-penn crept on [deck]1866-deck . [He]284-penn found [two boys]671-two boys in two tumbled heaps side by side on the main hatch , so deeply asleep that [he]284-penn actually rolled [them]671-two boys to [their]671-two boys berths . CHAPTER III It was the forty - fathom slumber that clears the soul and eye and heart , and sends [you]672-you to breakfast ravening . [They]673-they emptied a big tin dish of juicy fragments of fish - the blood - ends [the cook]628-the cook had collected overnight . [They]673-they cleaned up the plates and pans of [the elder mess , who were out fishing , sliced pork for the midday meal]675-the elder mess , who were out fishing , sliced pork for the midday meal , swabbed down the foc'sle , filled the lamps , drew coal and water for [the cook]628-the cook , and investigated the fore - hold , where [[the boat]528-the boat 's stores]678-the boat 's stores were stacked . It was another perfect day - soft , mild , and clear ; and [Harvey]250-harvey breathed to the very bottom of [his]250-harvey lungs . More schooners had crept up in the night , and the long blue seas were full of sails and dories . Far away on the horizon , the smoke of [some liner]679-some liner , [her]679-some liner hull invisible , smudged the blue , and to eastward [a big ship]680-a big ship 's top - gallant sails , just lifting , made a square nick in it . [Disko Troop]263-disko was smoking by the roof of [the cabin]569-the cabin - one eye on [the craft]682-the craft around , and the other on the little fly at the main - mast - head . " When [Dad]259-dad kerflummoxes that way , "[260-dan] said [Dan]260-dan in a whisper , " [he]259-dad 's doin' some high - line thinkin ' fer all hands . [I]260-dan 'll lay [my]260-dan wage an ' share [we]2087-we 'll make berth soon . [Dad]259-dad [he]259-dad knows the cod , an ' the Fleet [they]675-the elder mess , who were out fishing , sliced pork for the midday meal know [Dad]259-dad knows . ' See ['em]2088-'em comm ' up one by one , lookin ' fer nothin' in particular , o ' course , but scrowgin ' on [us]2087-we all the time ? There 's [the Prince Leboo]293-the prince leboo ; [she]293-the prince leboo 's [a Chat - ham boat]2089-a chat - ham boat . [She]293-the prince leboo 's crep ' up sence last night . An ' see that big one with a patch in [her]293-the prince leboo foresail an ' a new jib ? [She]293-the prince leboo 's [the Carrie Pitman from [West Chat - ham]45-west chat - ham]2090-the carrie pitman from west chat - ham . [She]293-the prince leboo wo n't keep [her]293-the prince leboo canvas long onless [her]293-the prince leboo luck 's changed since last season . [She]293-the prince leboo do n't do much ' cep ' drift . There ai n't an anchor made 'll hold [her]293-the prince leboo . . . . When the smoke puffs up in little rings like that , [Dad]259-dad 's studyin ' the fish . Ef [we]2087-we speak to [him]259-dad now , [he]259-dad 'll git mad . Las ' time [I]260-dan did , [he]259-dad jest took an ' hove a boot at [me]260-dan . "[260-dan] [Disko Troop]263-disko stared forward , the pipe between [his]263-disko teeth , with eyes that saw nothing . As [[his]263-disko son]1867-his son said , [he]263-disko was studying the fish - pitting [his]263-disko knowledge and experience on [the Banks]1897-the banks against the roving cod in [[his]263-disko own sea]685-his own sea . [He]263-disko accepted the presence of the inquisitive schooners on [the horizon]686-the horizon as a compliment to [his]263-disko powers . But now that it was paid , [he]263-disko wished to draw away and make [his]263-disko berth alone , till it was time to go up to [the Virgin]46-the virgin and fish in [the streets of [that roaring town]688-that roaring town upon [the waters]689-the waters]687-the streets of that roaring town upon the waters . So [Disko Troop]263-disko thought of recent weather , and gales , currents , food - supplies , and other domestic arrangements , from the point of view of a twenty - pound cod ; was , in fact , for an hour a cod [himself]263-disko , and looked remarkably like one . Then [he]263-disko removed the pipe from [his]263-disko teeth . " [Dad]259-dad , "[260-dan] said [Dan]260-dan , " [we]2091-we 've done [our]2091-we chores . Ca n't [we]2091-we go overside a piece ? It 's good catchin ' weather . "[260-dan] " Not in that cherry - coloured rig ner them ha'af baked brown shoes . Give [him]250-harvey suthin ' fit to wear . "[263-disko] " [Dad]259-dad 's pleased - that settles it , "[260-dan] said [Dan]260-dan , delightedly , dragging [Harvey]250-harvey into [the cabin]569-the cabin , while [Troop]260-dan pitched a key down the steps . " [Dad]259-dad keeps [my]263-disko spare rig where [he]259-dad kin overhaul it , 'cause [Ma]263-disko sez [I]263-disko 'm keerless . "[263-disko] [He]263-disko rummaged through a locker , and in less than three minutes [Harvey]250-harvey was adorned with [fisherman]691-fisherman 's rubber boots that came half up [his]250-harvey thigh , a heavy blue jersey well darned at the elbows , a pair of nippers , and a sou'wester . " Naow [ye]250-harvey look somethin' like , "[260-dan] said [Dan]260-dan . " Hurry ! "[260-dan] " Keep nigh an ' handy , "[260-dan] said [Troop]260-dan " an ' do n't go visitin ' raound [the Fleet]2092-the fleet . If [any one]562-any one asks [you]250-harvey what [I]260-dan 'm cal'latin ' to do , speak the truth - fer [ye]250-harvey do n't know . "[260-dan] A little red dory , labelled [Hattie S.]294-hattie , lay astern of [the schooner]553-the schooner . [Dan]260-dan hauled in the painter , and dropped lightly on to the bottom boards , while [Harvey]250-harvey tumbled clumsily after . " That 's no way o ' gettin ' into [a boat]2002-a boat , "[260-dan] said [Dan]260-dan . " Ef there was [any sea]2095-any sea [you]250-harvey 'd go to the bottom , sure . [You]250-harvey got to learn to meet [her]1817-the boy . "[260-dan] [Dan]260-dan fitted the thole - pins , took the forward thwart and watched [Harvey]250-harvey 's work . [The boy]1817-the boy had rowed , in a lady - like fashion , on [the Adirondack ponds]694-the adirondack ponds ; but there is a difference between squeaking pins and well - balanced ruflocks - light sculls and stubby , eight - foot sea - oars . They stuck in the gentle swell , and [Harvey]250-harvey grunted . " Short ! Row short ! "[260-dan] said [Dan]260-dan . " Ef [you]250-harvey cramp [your]250-harvey oar in any kind o ' sea [you]250-harvey 're liable to turn [her]1817-the boy over . Ai n't [she]1817-the boy a daisy ? [Mine]250-harvey , too . "[260-dan] [The little dory]695-the little dory was specklessly clean . In [her]695-the little dory bows lay a tiny anchor , two jugs of water , and some seventy fathoms of thin , brown dory - roding . A tin dinner - horn rested in cleats just under [Harvey]250-harvey 's right hand , beside [an ugly - looking maul]696-an ugly - looking maul , a short gaff , and a shorter wooden stick . A couple of lines , with very heavy leads and double cod - hooks , all neatly coiled on square reels , were stuck in their place by the gunwale . " Where 's the sail and mast ? "[250-harvey] said [Harvey]250-harvey , for [his]250-harvey hands were beginning to blister . [Dan]260-dan chuckled . " [Ye]250-harvey do n't sail fishin'-dories much . [Ye]250-harvey pull ; but [ye]250-harvey need n't pull so hard . Do n't [you]250-harvey wish [you]250-harvey owned [her]1817-the boy ? "[260-dan] " Well , [I]250-harvey guess [[my]250-harvey father]1910-my father might give [me]250-harvey one or two if [I]250-harvey asked ['em]2097-'em , "[250-harvey] [Harvey]250-harvey replied . [He]250-harvey had been too busy to think much of [[his]250-harvey family]697-his family till then . " That 's so . [I]260-dan forgot [[your]698-your dad]1872-your dad 's [a millionaire]1941-a millionaire . [You]698-your do n't act millionary any , naow . Do n't slitheroo thet way , [Harve]250-harvey . Short 's the trick , because [no sea]2103-no sea 's ever dead still , an ' the swells 'll - "[260-dan] Crack ! [I]250-harvey [he]1872-your dad d to learn too , but [I]250-harvey was n't more than eight years old when [I]250-harvey got [my]250-harvey schoolin ' . "[250-harvey] The " Portugee "[250-harvey] was rocking fully a mile away , but when [Dan]260-dan up - ended an oar [he]260-dan waved [his]260-dan left arm three times . " Thirty fathom , "[260-dan] said [Dan]260-dan , stringing a salt clam on to the hook . " Over with [the doughboys]2106-the doughboys . Bait same 's [I]260-dan do , [Harvey]250-harvey , an ' do n't snarl [your]250-harvey reel . "[260-dan] [Dan]260-dan 's line was out long before [Harvey]250-harvey had mastered the mystery of baiting and heaving out the leads . [The dory]520-the dory drifted along easily . It was not worth while to anchor till [they]520-the dory were sure of good ground . " Here [we]520-the dory come ! "[260-dan] [Dan]260-dan shouted , and a shower of spray rattled on [Harvey]250-harvey 's shoulders as a big cod flapped and kicked alongside . " Muckie , [Harvey]250-harvey , muckle ! Under [your]250-harvey hand ! Onick ! "[260-dan] Evidently " muckle "[260-dan] could not be the dinner - horn , so [Harvey]250-harvey passed over the maul , and [Dan]260-dan scientifically stunned the fish before [he]260-dan pulled it inboard , and wrenched out the hook with the short wooden stick [he]260-dan called a " gob - stick . "[260-dan] Then [Harvey]250-harvey felt a tug , and pulled up zealously . " Why , these are strawberries ! "[250-harvey] [he]250-harvey shouted . " Look ! "[250-harvey] The hook had fouled among a bunch of strawberries , red on one side and white on the other - perfect reproductions of the land fruit , except that there were no leaves , and the stem was all pipy and slimy . " Do n't tech 'em . Slat 'em off . Do n't - "[250-harvey] The warning came too late . [Harvey]250-harvey had picked them from the hook , and was admiring them . " Ouch ! "[250-harvey] [he]250-harvey cried , for [his]250-harvey fingers throbbed as though [he]250-harvey had grasped many nettles . " Now [ye]250-harvey know what strawberry - bottom means . Nothin' ' cep ' fish should be teched with the naked fingers , [Dad]259-dad says . Slat 'em off agin the gunnel , an ' bait up , Harve . Lookin ' wo n't help any . It 's all in the wages . "[250-harvey] [Harvey]250-harvey smiled at the thought of [his]250-harvey ten and a half dollars a month , and wondered what [[his]250-harvey mother]1807-his mother would say if [she]1807-his mother could see [him]250-harvey hanging over the edge of a fishing - dory in [mid - ocean]1854-mid - ocean . [She]1807-his mother suffered agonies whenever [he]250-harvey went out on [Saranac Lake]47-saranac lake ; and , by the way , [Harvey]250-harvey remembered distinctly that [he]250-harvey used to laugh at [her]1807-his mother anxieties . Suddenly the line flashed through [his]250-harvey hand , stinging even through the " nippers , "[260-dan] the woolen circlets supposed to protect it . " [He]250-harvey 's [a logy]2107-a logy . Give [him]250-harvey room accordin ' to [his]250-harvey strength , "[260-dan] cried [Dan]260-dan . " [I]260-dan 'll help [ye]250-harvey . "[260-dan] " No , [you]260-dan wo n't , "[250-harvey] [Harvey]250-harvey snapped , as [he]250-harvey hung on to the line . " It 's [my]250-harvey first fish . [I]250-harvey - is it a whale ? "[250-harvey] " [Halibut]295-halibut , [mebbe]2083-mebbe . "[260-dan] [Dan]260-dan peered down into the water alongside , and flourished [the big " muckle]2109-the big " muckle , "[2109-the big " muckle] ready for all chances . Something white and oval flickered and fluttered through the green . " [I]250-harvey 'll lay [my]250-harvey wage an ' share [he]295-halibut 's over a hundred . Are [you]260-dan so everlastin ' anxious to land [him]295-halibut alone ? "[250-harvey] [Harvey]250-harvey 's knuckles were raw and bleeding where they had been hanged against the gunwale ; [his]250-harvey face was purple - blue between excitement and exertion ; [he]250-harvey dripped with sweat , and was half - blinded from staring at the circling sunlit ripples about the swiftly moving line . [The boys]703-the boys were tired long ere the halibut , who took charge of [them]703-the boys and [the dory]520-the dory for the next twenty minutes . But the big flat fish was gaffed and hauled in at last . " [Beginner]2110-beginner 's luck , "[260-dan] said [Dan]260-dan , wiping [his]260-dan forehead . " [He]295-halibut 's all of a hundred . "[260-dan] [Harvey]250-harvey looked at the huge gray - and - mottled creature with unspeakable pride . [He]250-harvey had seen halibut many times on marble slabs ashore , but it had never occurred to [him]250-harvey to ask how [they]705-they came inland . Now [he]250-harvey knew ; and every inch of [his]250-harvey body ached with fatigue . " Ef [Dad]259-dad was along , "[260-dan] said [Dan]260-dan , hauling up , " [he]259-dad 'd read the signs plain 's print . [The fish]2111-the fish are runnin ' smaller an ' smaller , an ' [you]260-dan 've took ' baout as logy a halibut 's [we]703-the boys 're apt to find this trip . [Yesterday]296-yesterday 's catch - did [ye]260-dan notice it ? - was all big fish an ' [no halibut]2112-no halibut . [Dad]259-dad [he]259-dad 'd read them signs right off . "[260-dan] [Even]706-even as [he]250-harvey spoke [some one]707-some one fired a pistol on the ' [We]708-we 're Here ' , and a potato - basket was run up in the fore - rigging . " What did [I]708-we say , naow ? That 's the call fer [the whole crowd]2115-the whole crowd . [Dad]259-dad 's onter something , er [he]259-dad 'd never break fishin ' this time o ' day . "[708-we] [They]708-we were to windward of [the schooner]553-the schooner , just ready to flirt [the dory]520-the dory over [the still sea]626-the still sea , when sounds of woe half a mile off led [them]708-we to [Penn]284-penn , who was careering around [a fixed point for all the world]712-a fixed point for all the world like a gigantic water - bug . " [We]708-we 'll [hev]2116-hev to help [him]713-the little man , else [he]713-the little man 'll root an ' seed here , "[260-dan] said [Dan]260-dan . " What 's the matter ? "[250-harvey] said [Harvey]250-harvey . This was [a new world]714-a new world , where [he]713-the little man could not lay down the law to [[his]713-the little man elders]715-his elders , but had to ask questions humbly . And [the sea]1855-the sea was horribly big and unexcited . " [Anchor]2117-anchor 's fouled . [Penn]284-penn 's always losing ['em]2118-'em . Lost two this trip a'ready - on sandy bottom too - an ' [Dad]259-dad says next one [he]259-dad loses , sure 's fishin ' , [he]259-dad 'll give [him]259-dad [the kelleg]2119-the kelleg . That ' u'd break [Penn]284-penn 's heart . "[250-harvey] " What 's a ' kelleg ' ? " Big stone instid of an anchor . [You]2120-you kin see a kelleg ridin ' in the bows fur 's [you]2120-you can see a dory , an ' all [the fleet]2092-the fleet knows what it means . [They]2092-the fleet 'd guy [him]284-penn dreadful . [Penn]284-penn could n't stand that no more'n a dog with a dipper to [his]284-penn tail . [He]284-penn 's so everlastin ' sensitive . Hello , [Penn]284-penn ! Stuck again ? Do n't try any more o ' [your]284-penn patents . Come up on [her]2119-the kelleg , and keep [your]284-penn rodin ' straight up an ' down . "[250-harvey] " It does n't move , "[713-the little man] said [the little man]713-the little man , panting . " It does n't move at all , and instead [I]713-the little man tried everything . "[713-the little man] " What 's all this hurrah's - nest for'ard ? "[260-dan] said [Dan]260-dan , pointing to a wild tangle of spare oars and dory - roding , all matted together by the hand of inexperience . " Oh , that , "[284-penn] said [Penn]284-penn proudly , " is a Spanish windlass . [Mr. Salters]285-salters showed [me]284-penn how to make it ; but even that does n't move [her]2119-the kelleg . "[284-penn] [Dan]260-dan bent low over the gunwale to hide a smile , twitched once or twice on the roding , and , behold , the anchor drew at once . " Haul up , [Penn]284-penn , "[260-dan] [he]260-dan said laughing , " er [she]2119-the kelleg 'll git stuck again . "[260-dan] [They]719-they left [him]260-dan regarding the weed - hung flukes of the little anchor with big , pathetic blue eyes , and thanking [them]719-they profusely . " Oh , say , while [I]260-dan think of it , [Harve]250-harvey , "[260-dan] said [Dan]260-dan when [they]719-they were out of ear - shot , " [Penn]284-penn ai n't quite all caulked . " [Dad]259-dad ai n't mistook this time . [Penn]284-penn 's [a sure 'nuff loony]2123-a sure 'nuff loony . "[250-harvey] " No , [he]284-penn ai n't thet exactly , so much ez a harmless ijut . It was this way [you]250-harvey 're rowin ' quite so , [Harve]250-harvey , an ' [I]250-harvey tell [you]250-harvey 'cause it 's right [you]250-harvey orter know . [He]284-penn was [a Moravian preacher]2124-a moravian preacher once . [Jacob Boiler]297-jacob boiler wuz [his]297-jacob boiler name , [Dad]259-dad told [me]250-harvey , an ' [he]297-jacob boiler lived with [[his]297-jacob boiler wife]1815-his wife an ' [four children]2126-four children somewheres out [Pennsylvania]36-pennsylvania way . [You]250-harvey 've heered talk o ' [Johnstown]48-johnstown ? "[250-harvey] [Harvey]250-harvey considered . " Yes , [I]250-harvey have . But [I]250-harvey do n't know why . It drove steadily and in wreaths , curling and smoking along [the colourless water]730-the colourless water . [The men]1868-the men stopped dressing - down without a word . "[273-long jack] " ' Tain't [my]260-dan trick this time , "[260-dan] grinned [Dan]260-dan . " [You]260-dan 've got to go it alone . [Dad]259-dad learned [me]260-dan with a rope 's end . "[260-dan] For an hour [Long Jack]273-long jack walked [his]273-long jack prey up and down , teaching , as [he]273-long jack said , " things at [the sea]1855-the sea that [ivry man]2196-ivry man must know , blind , dhrunk , or asleep . "[273-long jack] There is not much gear to [a seventy - ton schooner]666-a seventy - ton schooner with a stump - foremast , but [Long Jack]273-long jack had a gift of expression . When [he]273-long jack wished to draw [Harvey]250-harvey 's attention to the peak - halyards , [he]273-long jack dug [his]273-long jack knuckles into the back of [the boy]1817-the boy 's neck and kept [him]1817-the boy at gaze for half a minute . [He]273-long jack emphasized the difference between fore and aft generally by rubbing [Harvey]250-harvey 's nose along a few feet of the boom , and the lead of each rope was fixed in [Harvey]250-harvey 's mind by the end of the rope itself . The lesson would have been easier had the deck been at all free ; but there appeared to be a place on [it]744-it for everything and anything except [a man]504-a man . Forward lay the windlass and its tackle , with the chain and hemp cables , all very unpleasant to trip over ; the foc'sle stovepipe , and the gurry - butts by the foc'sle hatch to hold the fish - livers . Aft of these the foreboom and booby of the main - hatch took all the space that was not needed for the pumps and dressing - pens . Then came the nests of dories lashed to ring - bolts by [the quarter - deck]549-the quarter - deck ; [the house]736-the house , with tubs and oddments lashed all around [it]736-the house ; and , last , the sixty - foot main - boom in its crutch , splitting things length - wise , to duck and dodge under every time . [Tom Platt]274-tom platt , of course , could not keep [his]274-tom platt oar out of the business , but ranged alongside with enormous and unnecessary descriptions of sails and spars on [the old Ohio]39-ohio . " [Niver]311-niver mind fwhat [he]274-tom platt says ; attind to [me]274-tom platt , Innocince . [Tom Platt]274-tom platt , this bally - hoo 's not [the Ohio]39-ohio , an ' [you]274-tom platt 're mixing the bhoy bad . "[274-tom platt] " [He]274-tom platt 'll be ruined for life , beginnin ' on a fore - an'-after this way , "[274-tom platt] [Tom Platt]274-tom platt pleaded . " Give [him]274-tom platt a chance to know a few leadin ' principles . "[274-tom platt] said [Tom Platt]274-tom platt , in a professional agony . " Lower the throat and peak halyards , "[250-harvey] [Harvey]250-harvey went on . " Lower till that rope - loop - on the after - leach - kris - no , it 's cringle - till the cringle was down on the boom . "[250-harvey] " [You]250-harvey 've forgot to pass the tack - earing , but wid time and help [ye'll]250-harvey larn . There 's good and just reason for ivry rope aboard , or else ' twould be overboard . [D'ye]250-harvey follow [me]748-i ? ' Tis dollars an ' cents [I]748-i 'm puttin ' into [your]250-harvey pocket , [ye]250-harvey skinny little supercargo , so that fwhin [ye've]250-harvey filled out [ye]250-harvey can ship from [Boston]23-boston to [Cuba]60-cuba an ' tell [thim Long Jack]273-long jack larned [you]250-harvey . Now [I]748-i 'll chase [ye]250-harvey around a piece , callin ' the ropes , an ' [you]250-harvey 'll lay [your]250-harvey hand on thim as [I]748-i call . "[748-i] [He]748-i began , and [Harvey]250-harvey , who was feeling rather tired , walked slowly to the rope named . A rope 's end licked round [his]250-harvey ribs , and nearly knocked the breath out of [him]250-harvey . " When [you]250-harvey own [a boat]2002-a boat , "[274-tom platt] said [Tom Platt]274-tom platt , with severe eyes , " [you]250-harvey can walk . Till then , take all orders at the run . Once more - to make sure ! "[274-tom platt] [Harvey]250-harvey was in a glow with the exercise , and this last cut warmed [him]250-harvey thoroughly . Now [he]250-harvey was [a singularly smart boy]749-a singularly smart boy , [the son of [a very clever man]751-a very clever man]750-the son of a very clever man and [a very sensitive woman]752-a very sensitive woman , with a fine resolute temper that systematic spoiling had nearly turned to mulish obstinacy . [He]250-harvey looked at [the other men]753-the other men , and saw that even [Dan]260-dan did not smile . It was evidently all in the day 's work , though it hurt abominably ; so [he]250-harvey swallowed the hint with a gulp and a gasp and a grin . The same smartness that led [him]250-harvey to take such advantage of [[his]250-harvey mother]1807-his mother made [him]250-harvey very sure that [no one on [the boat]528-the boat]755-no one on the boat , except , maybe , [Penn]300-penn , would stand the least nonsense . [One]2031-one learns a great deal from a mere tone . [Long Jack]273-long jack called over half a dozen ropes , and [Harvey]250-harvey danced over [the deck]517-the deck like an eel at ebb - tide , one eye on [Tom Platt]274-tom platt . " Ver ' good . Ver ' good don , "[272-manuel] said [Manuel]272-manuel . " After supper [I]272-manuel show [you]250-harvey [a little schooner [I]272-manuel make]2200-a little schooner i make , with all [her]2200-a little schooner i make ropes . So [we]2201-we shall learn . "[272-manuel] " Fust - class fer - [a passenger]2019-a passenger , "[260-dan] said [Dan]260-dan . " [Dad]259-dad [he]259-dad 's jest allowed [you]250-harvey 'll be wuth [your]250-harvey salt maybe ' fore [you]250-harvey 're draownded . Thet 's a heap fer [Dad]259-dad . [I]260-dan 'll learn [you]250-harvey more [our]2201-we next watch together . "[260-dan] " [Taller]312-taller ! "[263-disko] grunted [Disko]263-disko , peering through the fog as it smoked over the bows . There was nothing to be seen ten feet beyond the surging jib - boom , while alongside rolled the endless procession of solemn , pale waves whispering and lipping one to the other . " Now [I]274-tom platt 'll learn [you]250-harvey something [Long Jack]273-long jack ca n't , "[274-tom platt] shouted [Tom Platt]274-tom platt , as from a locker by the stern [he]274-tom platt produced a battered deep - sea lead hollowed at one end , smeared the hollow from a saucer full of mutton tallow , and went forward . " [I]263-disko 'll learn [you]250-harvey how to fly the Blue Pigeon . Shooo ! "[263-disko] [Disko]263-disko did something to the wheel that checked [the schooner]553-the schooner 's way , while [Manuel]272-manuel , with [Harvey]250-harvey to help and [a proud boy]760-a proud boy was [Harvey]250-harvey , let down the jib in a lump on the boom . [The lead]761-the lead sung a deep droning song as [Tom Platt]274-tom platt whirled it round and round . " Go ahead , [man]2003-man , "[273-long jack] said [Long Jack]273-long jack , impatiently . " [We]2204-we 're not drawin ' twenty - five fut off [Fire Island]61-fire island in a fog . There 's no trick to ut . "[273-long jack] " Do n't be jealous , [Galway]313-galway . "[762-the released lead] [The released lead]762-the released lead plopped into [the sea]1855-the sea far ahead as [the schooner]553-the schooner surged slowly forward . " Soundin ' is a trick , though , "[260-dan] said [Dan]260-dan , " when [your]313-galway dipsey lead 's all the eye [you]313-galway 're like to hev for a week . What d'you make it , [Dad]259-dad ? "[260-dan] [Disko]263-disko 's face relaxed . [The schooner]553-the schooner seemed to be straying promiscuously through the smother , [her]553-the schooner headsail banging wildly . " Now haow in thunder did [Dad]259-dad know ? Help [us]771-they here , [Harve]250-harvey . It 's a big un . Poke - hooked , too . "[771-they] [They]771-they hauled together , and landed a goggle - eyed twenty - pound cod . [He]274-tom platt had taken the bait right into [his]274-tom platt stomach . " Are [they]771-they good to eat ? "[250-harvey] [Harvey]250-harvey panted , as [he]250-harvey lugged in another crab - covered cod . " Sure . Never mind how the bait sets . [They]771-they 'll bite on the bare hook . "[250-harvey] " Say , this is great ! "[250-harvey] [Harvey]250-harvey cried , as the fish came in gasping and splashing - nearly all poke - hooked , as [Dan]260-dan had said . " Why ca n't [we]771-they always fish from [the boat]528-the boat instead of from [the dories]552-the dories ? "[260-dan] " [Allus]315-allus can , till [we]771-they begin to dress daown . Efter thet , the heads and offals ' u'd scare the fish to [Fundy]63-fundy . Boatfishin ' ai n't reckoned progressive , though , unless [ye]777-ye know as much as [dad]1947-dad knows . Guess [we]771-they 'll run aout aour trawl to - night . Harder on the back , this , than frum the dory , ai n't it ? "[260-dan] It was rather back - breaking work , for in a dory the weight of a cod is water - borne till the last minute , and [you]777-ye are , so to speak , abreast of [him]778-him ; but the few feet of [a schooner]779-a schooner 's freeboard make so much extra dead - hauling , and stooping over the bulwarks cramps the stomach . But it was wild and furious sport so long as it lasted ; and a big pile lay aboard when the fish ceased biting . " Where 's [Penn]300-penn and [Uncle Salters]276-uncle salters ? "[250-harvey] [Harvey]250-harvey asked , slapping the slime off [his]250-harvey oilskins , and reeling up the line in careful imitation of [the others]620-the others . " Git 's coffee and see . "[263-disko] That meant [the boys]703-the boys would bait with selected offal of the cod as the fish were cleaned - an improvement on paddling bare - handed in the little bait - barrels below . The tubs were full of neatly coiled line carrying a big hook each few feet ; and the testing and baiting of every single hook , with the stowage of the baited line so that it should run clear when shot from [the dory]520-the dory , was a scientific business . [Dan]260-dan managed it in the dark , without looking , while [Harvey]250-harvey caught [his]250-harvey fingers on the barbs and bewailed [his]250-harvey fate . But the hooks flew through [Dan]260-dan 's fingers like tatting on [an old maid]787-an old maid 's lap . "[284-penn] [Penn]284-penn and [Uncle Salters]276-uncle salters cleaned up as [Disko]263-disko had ordained , but [the boys]703-the boys profited little . No sooner were the tubs furnished than [Tom Platt]274-tom platt and [Long Jack]273-long jack , who had been exploring the inside of [a dory]790-a dory with a lantern , snatched them away , loaded up the tubs and some small , painted trawl - buoys , and hove [the boat]528-the boat overboard into what [Harvey]250-harvey regarded as [an exceedingly rough sea]792-an exceedingly rough sea . " [They]703-the boys 'll be drowned . Why , [the dory]520-the dory 's loaded like [a freight - car]2222-a freight - car , "[250-harvey] [he]250-harvey cried . "[273-long jack] [The dory]520-the dory surged up on the crest of a wave , and just when it seemed impossible that [she]520-the dory could avoid smashing against [the schooner]553-the schooner 's side , slid over [the ridge]795-the ridge , and was swallowed up in the damp dusk . " Take ahold here , an ' keep ringin ' steady , "[260-dan] said [Dan]260-dan , passing [Harvey]250-harvey the lanyard of a bell that hung just behind the windlass . [Harvey]250-harvey rang lustily , for [he]250-harvey felt two lives depended on [him]250-harvey . But [Disko]263-disko in [the cabin]569-the cabin , scrawling in the log - book , did not look like [a murderer]797-a murderer , and when [he]263-disko went to supper [he]263-disko even smiled dryly at the anxious [Harvey]250-harvey . " This ai n't no weather , "[260-dan] said [Dan]260-dan . " Why , [you]250-harvey an ' [me]260-dan could set thet trawl ! "[250-harvey] [Harvey]250-harvey kept it up , varied with occasional rub - a - dubs , for another half - hour . There was a bellow and a bump alongside . [Manuel]272-manuel and [Dan]260-dan raced to the hooks of the dory - tackle ; [Long Jack]273-long jack and [Tom Platt]274-tom platt arrived on [deck]1866-deck together , it seemed , one half the [North Atlantic]64-north atlantic at [their]799-they backs , and the dory followed [them]799-they in the air , landing with a clatter . " [Nary]318-nary snarl , "[274-tom platt] said [Tom Platt]274-tom platt as [he]274-tom platt dripped . " [Danny]260-dan , [you]260-dan 'll do yet . " [We]799-they do be condescending to honour the second half wid [our]799-they presence . "[273-long jack] And off [they]799-they all four rolled to supper , where [Harvey]250-harvey stuffed [himself]250-harvey to the brim on fish - chowder and fried pies , and fell fast asleep just as [Manuel]272-manuel produced from a locker a lovely two - foot model of the [Lucy Holmes]319-lucy holmes , [[his]272-manuel first boat]800-his first boat , and was going to show [Harvey]250-harvey the ropes . " It must be a sad thing - a very sad thing , "[284-penn] said [Penn]284-penn , watching [the boy]1817-the boy 's face , " for [[his]1817-the boy mother]1807-his mother and [[his]1817-the boy father]1810-his father , who think [he]1817-the boy is dead . " Expec ' [he]1817-the boy make [good man]2231-good man , [Danny]260-dan . [I]260-dan no see [he]1817-the boy is any so mad as [your]260-dan parpa [he]1817-the boy says . Eh , wha - at ? "[260-dan] [Dan]260-dan chuckled , but the chuckle ended in a snore . It was thick weather outside , with a rising wind , and [the elder men]627-the elder men stretched [their]627-the elder men watches . The hour struck clear in [the cabin]569-the cabin ; the nosing bows slapped and scuffed with the seas ; the foc'sle stove - pipe hissed and sputtered as the spray caught it ; and [the boys]703-the boys slept on , while [Disko]263-disko , [Long Jack]273-long jack , [Tom Platt]274-tom platt , and [Uncle Salters]276-uncle salters , [each in turn]805-each in turn , stumped aft to look at the wheel , forward to see that the anchor held , or to veer out a little more cable against chafing , with a glance at the dim anchor - light between each round . CHAPTER IV [Harvey]250-harvey waked to find the " first half "[250-harvey] at breakfast , the foc'sle door drawn to a crack , and every square inch of [the schooner]553-the schooner singing its own tune . The black bulk of [the cook]628-the cook balanced behind the tiny galley over the glare of the stove , and the pots and pans in the pierced wooden board before it jarred and racketed to each plunge . Up and up [the foc'sle]808-the foc'sle climbed , yearning and surging and quivering , and then , with a clear , sickle - like swoop , came down into the seas . [He]250-harvey could hear the flaring bows cut and squelch , and there was a pause ere the divided waters came down on [the deck]517-the deck above , like a volley of buckshot . Followed the woolly sound of the cable in the hawse - hole ; and a grunt and squeal of the windlass ; a yaw , a punt , and a kick , and the ' [We]810-we 're Here ' gathered [herself]811-herself together to repeat the motions . " Now , [ashore]2232-ashore , "[273-long jack] [he]250-harvey heard [Long Jack]273-long jack saying , " ye've chores , an ' [ye]250-harvey must do thim in any weather . Here [we]810-we 're well clear of [the fleet]2092-the fleet , an ' [we]810-we 've no chores - an ' that 's a blessin ' . Good night , all . "[273-long jack] [He]250-harvey passed like a big snake from the table to [his]250-harvey bunk , and began to smoke . [Tom Platt]274-tom platt followed [his]250-harvey example ; [Uncle Salters]276-uncle salters , with [Penn]284-penn , fought [his]276-uncle salters way up the ladder to stand [his]276-uncle salters watch , and [the cook set for the ' second half]812-the cook set for the ' second half . " [It]2234-it came out of [its]2234-it bunks as [the others]620-the others had entered [theirs]620-the others , with a shake and a yawn . [It]2234-it ate till [it]2234-it could eat no more ; and then [Manuel]272-manuel filled [his]272-manuel pipe with some terrible tobacco , crotched [himself]272-manuel between the pawl - post and a forward bunk , cocked [his]272-manuel feet up on the table , and smiled tender and indolent smiles at the smoke . [Dan]260-dan lay at length in [[his]260-dan bunk]2236-his bunk , wrestling with a gaudy , gilt - stopped accordion , whose tunes went up and down with the pitching of the ' [We]2237-we 're Here ' . [The cook]628-the cook , [his]628-the cook shoulders against the locker where [he]628-the cook kept the fried pies [Dan]260-dan was fond of fried pies , peeled potatoes , with one eye on the stove in event of too much water finding its way down the pipe ; and the general smell and smother were past all description . [Harvey]250-harvey considered affairs , wondered that [he]250-harvey was not deathly sick , and crawled into [his]250-harvey bunk again , as the softest and safest place , while [Dan]260-dan struck up , "[0-i] [I]0-i do n't want to play in [[your]813-you yard]814-your yard , " as accurately as the wild jerks allowed . "[0-i] How long is this for ? " [Harvey]250-harvey asked of [Manuel]272-manuel . "[815-she] Till [she]815-she get a little quiet , and [we]816-we can row to trawl . Perhaps to - night . Perhaps two days more . [You]813-you do not like ? Eh , wha - at ? " "[0-i] [I]0-i should have been crazy sick a week ago , but it does n't seem to upset [me]0-i now - much . " "[816-we] That is because [we]816-we make [you]813-you fisherman , these days . If [I]0-i was [you]813-you , when [I]0-i come to [Gloucester]19-gloucester [I]0-i would give two , three big candles for [my]0-i good luck . " "[0-i] Give who ? " "[0-i] To be sure - [the Virgin of [[our]816-we Church on [the Hill]65-the hill]818-our church on the hill]817-the virgin of our church on the hill . [She]817-the virgin of our church on the hill is very good to [fishermen]1965-fishermen all the time . That is why [so few of [[us]816-we Portugee men]821-us portugee men]820-so few of us portugee men ever are drowned . " "[813-you] [You]813-you 're [a Roman Catholic]822-a roman catholic , then ? " "[813-you] [I]0-i am [a Madeira man]823-a madeira man . [I]0-i am not [a Porto Pico boy]824-a porto pico boy . Shall [I]0-i be [Baptist]320-baptist , then ? Eh , wha - at ? [I]0-i always give candles - two , three more when [I]0-i come to [Gloucester]19-gloucester . [The good Virgin]825-the good virgin [she]817-the virgin of our church on the hill never forgets [me]0-i , [Manuel]272-manuel . " "[272-manuel] [I]0-i do n't sense it that way , " [Tom Platt]274-tom platt put in from [his]274-tom platt bunk , [his]274-tom platt scarred face lit up by the glare of a match as [he]274-tom platt sucked at [his]274-tom platt pipe . "[0-i] It stands to reason [the sea]1855-the sea 's [the sea]1855-the sea ; and [you]272-manuel 'll get jest about what 's goin' , candles or kerosene , fer that matter . " "[272-manuel] ' Tis a mighty good thing , " said [Long Jack]273-long jack , "[272-manuel] to have [a friend]828-a friend at coort , though . [I]0-i 'm o ' [Manuel]272-manuel 's way o ' thinkin ' About tin years back [I]0-i was crew to [a Sou ' Boston market - boat]829-a sou ' boston market - boat . [We]830-we was off [Minot 's Ledge]66-minot 's ledge wid a northeaster , butt first , atop of [us]830-we , [thicker'n burgoo]831-thicker'n burgoo . [The ould man]832-the ould man was dhrunk , [his]832-the ould man chin waggin ' on the tiller , an ' [I]0-i sez to [myself]0-i , ' If iver [I]0-i stick [[my]0-i boat]833-my boat - huk into [T - wharf]834-t - wharf again , [I]0-i 'll show [the saints]835-the saints fwhat manner o ' craft [they]835-the saints saved [me]0-i out av . ' Now , [I]0-i 'm [here]1800-here , as [ye]837-ye can well see , an ' the model of [the dhirty ould Kathleen]838-the dhirty ould kathleen , that took [me]0-i a month to make , [I]0-i gave ut to [the priest]839-the priest , an ' [he]839-the priest hung [ut]840-ut up forninst the altar . There 's more sense in givin ' a model that 's by way o ' bein ' a work av art than any candle . [Ye]837-ye can buy candles at [store]841-store , but a model shows the good saints ye've tuk trouble an ' are grateful . " "[321-irish] D'you believe that , [Irish]321-irish ? " said [Tom Platt]274-tom platt , turning on [his]274-tom platt elbow . "[321-irish] Would [I]0-i do ut if [I]0-i did not , [Ohio]39-ohio ? " "[322-enoch fuller] Wa - al , [Enoch Fuller]322-enoch fuller [he]322-enoch fuller made a model o ' [the old Ohio]842-the old ohio , and [she]843-she 's to [Calem museum]844-calem museum now . [Mighty pretty model]845-mighty pretty model , too , but [I]0-i guess [Enoch]322-enoch fuller [he]322-enoch fuller never done it fer no sacrifice ; an ' the way [I]0-i take it is - " There were the makings of an hour - long discussion of the kind that [fishermen love , where the talk runs in shouting circles]2239-fishermen love , where the talk runs in shouting circles and [no one]1898-no one proves anything at the end , had not [Dan]260-dan struck up this cheerful rhyme : "[322-enoch fuller] Up jumped the mackerel with [his]322-enoch fuller stripe'd back . Reef in the mainsail , and haul on the tack ; For it 's windy weather - " Here Long [Jack]273-long jack joined in : And it 's blowy weather ; When the winds begin to blow , pipe all hands together ! "[260-dan] [Dan]260-dan went on , with a cautious look at [Tom Platt]274-tom platt , holding the accordion low in the bunk : " [Up]323-up jumped the cod with [his]274-tom platt chuckle - head , Went to the main - chains to heave at the lead ; For it 's windy weather , "[274-tom platt] etc . [Tom Platt]274-tom platt seemed to be hunting for something . [Dan]260-dan crouched lower , but sang louder : " Up jumped the flounder that swims to the ground . Chuckle - head ! Chuckle - head ! Mind where [ye]260-dan sound ! "[260-dan] [Tom Platt]274-tom platt 's huge rubber boot whirled across the foc'sle and caught [Dan]260-dan 's uplifted arm . There was war between [the man]515-the man and [the boy]1817-the boy ever since [Dan]260-dan had discovered that the mere whistling of that tune would make [him]260-dan angry as [he]260-dan heaved the lead . " Thought [I]260-dan 'd fetch [yer]260-dan , "[260-dan] said [Dan]260-dan , returning the gift with precision . " Ef [you]260-dan do n't like [my]260-dan music , git out [your]260-dan fiddle . [I]260-dan ai n't goin' to lie here all day an ' listen to [you]260-dan an ' Long Jack arguin ' ' baout candles . Fiddle , [Tom Platt]274-tom platt ; or [I]260-dan 'll learn Harve here the tune ! "[260-dan] [Tom Platt]274-tom platt leaned down to a locker and brought up an old white fiddle . [Manuel]272-manuel 's eye glistened , and from somewhere behind the pawl - post [he]272-manuel drew out a tiny , guitar - like thing with wire strings , which [he]272-manuel called a machette . " ' Tis a concert , "[273-long jack] said [Long Jack]273-long jack , beaming through the smoke . " A reg'lar [Boston]23-boston concert . "[273-long jack] There was a burst of spray as the hatch opened , and [Disko]263-disko , in yellow oilskins , descended . " [Ye're]260-dan just in time , [Disko]263-disko . Fwhat 's [she]2241-she doin' outside ? "[263-disko] " Jest this ! "[273-long jack] [He]273-long jack dropped on to the lockers with the push and heave of the ' [We]848-we 're Here ' . " [We]848-we 're singin ' to kape [our]848-we breakfasts down . [Ye'll]260-dan lead , av course , [Disko]263-disko , "[273-long jack] said [Long Jack]273-long jack . " Guess there ai n't more'n ' baout two old songs [I]273-long jack know , an ' [ye've]260-dan heerd [them]2242-them both . "[273-long jack] [His]273-long jack excuses were cut short by [Tom Platt]274-tom platt launching into a most dolorous tune , like unto the moaning of winds and the creaking of masts . With [his]273-long jack eyes fixed on the beams above , [Disko]263-disko began this ancient , ancient ditty , [Tom Platt]274-tom platt flourishing all round [him]273-long jack to make the tune and words fit a little : " There is a crack packet - crack packet o ' fame , [She]2241-she hails from [Noo York]67-noo york , an ' [the Dreadnought]2243-the dreadnought 's [her]2241-she name . [You]2244-you may talk o ' [your]2244-you fliers - Swallowtail and Black Ball - But [the Dreadnought]68-the dreadnought 's the packet that can beat [them]2245-them all . "[274-tom platt] Now [the Dreadnought]68-the dreadnought [she]68-the dreadnought lies in [the River Mersey]69-the river mersey , Because of [the tug - boat]849-the tug - boat to take [her]68-the dreadnought to [sea]2042-sea ; But when [she]68-the dreadnought 's off soundings [you]851-you shortly will know Chorus . [She]68-the dreadnought 's the [Liverpool]70-liverpool packet - Lord , let [her]68-the dreadnought go ! " Now [the Dreadnought]68-the dreadnought [she]68-the dreadnought 's howlin ' crost [the Banks o ' [Newfoundland]71-newfoundland]2246-the banks o ' newfoundland , Where [the water 's all shallow]2247-the water 's all shallow and the bottom 's all sand . Sez all the little fishes that swim to and fro : Chorus . ' [She]68-the dreadnought 's the [Liverpool]70-liverpool packet - Lord , let [her]68-the dreadnought go ! ' "[852-he] , There were scores of verses , for [he]852-he worked the Dreadnought every mile of the way between [Liverpool]70-liverpool and [New York]8-new york as conscientiously as though [he]852-he were on [[her]68-the dreadnought deck]853-her deck , and the accordion pumped and the fiddle squeaked beside [him]852-he . [Tom Platt]274-tom platt followed with something about " the rough and tough [McGinn]325-mcginn , who would pilot [the vessel]2248-the vessel in . "[274-tom platt] Then [they]854-they called on [Harvey]250-harvey , who felt very flattered , to contribute to the entertainment ; but all that [he]250-harvey could remember were some pieces of " [Skipper Ireson]326-skipper ireson 's Ride "[854-they] that [he]250-harvey had been taught at [[the camp]855-the camp - school in [the Adirondacks]18-the adirondacks]856-the camp - school in the adirondacks . It seemed that they might be appropriate to the time and place , but [he]250-harvey had no more than mentioned the title when [Disko]263-disko brought down one foot with a bang , and cried , " Do n't go on , [young feller]1873-young feller . That 's a mistaken jedgment - one o ' the worst kind , too , becaze it 's catchin ' to the ear . "[263-disko] " [I]260-dan orter ha ' warned [you]263-disko , "[260-dan] said [Dan]260-dan . " Thet allus fetches [Dad]259-dad . "[260-dan] " What 's wrong ? "[250-harvey] said [Harvey]250-harvey , surprised and a little angry . " All [you]1873-young feller 're goin' to say , "[263-disko] said [Disko]263-disko . " All dead wrong from start to finish , an ' Whittier [he]259-dad 's to blame . [I]263-disko have no special call to right [any Marblehead man]2250-any marblehead man , but ' tweren't no fault o ' [Ireson]326-skipper ireson 's . [[My]263-disko father]1910-my father [he]1910-my father told [me]263-disko the tale time an ' again , an ' this is the way ' twuz . "[263-disko] " For the wan hundredth time , "[273-long jack] put in [Long Jack]273-long jack under [his]273-long jack breath " [Ben Ireson]327-ireson [he]327-ireson was skipper o ' [the Betty]2252-the betty , [young feller]1873-young feller , comin ' [home]545-home [frum]2255-frum [the Banks]44-the banks - that was before the war of 1812 , but jestice is jestice at all times . [They]2256-they fund [the Active o ' [Portland]72-the active o ' portland]72-the active o ' portland , an ' [Gibbons o ' [that town]2258-that town]2257-gibbons o ' that town [he]327-ireson was [[her]2252-the betty skipper]2166-her skipper ; [they]2256-they fund [her]2252-the betty leakin ' off [Cape Cod Light]74-cape cod light . There was a terr'ble gale on , an ' [they]2256-they was gettin ' [the Betty]2252-the betty [home]545-home 's fast as [they]2256-they could craowd [her]2252-the betty . Well , [Ireson]327-ireson [he]327-ireson said there warn't any sense to reskin ' [a boat]2002-a boat in [that sea]2263-that sea ; [the men]1868-the men [they]1868-the men would n't [hev]2265-hev it ; and [he]327-ireson laid it before [them]1868-the men to stay by [the Active]2266-the active till [the sea]1855-the sea run daown a piece . [They]1868-the men would n't [hev]2265-hev that either , hangin ' araound [the Cape]75-the cape in any sech weather , leak or no leak . [They]1868-the men jest up stays'l an ' quit , nat'rally takin ' [Ireson]327-ireson with ['em]2268-'em . [Folks to [Marblehead]76-marblehead]2269-folks to marblehead was mad at [him]327-ireson not runnin ' the risk , and becaze nex ' day , when [the sea]1855-the sea was ca'am [they]1868-the men never stopped to think o ' that , [some of [the Active 's folks]2272-the active 's folks]2271-some of the active 's folks was took off by [a Truro man]2273-a truro man . [They]2271-some of the active 's folks come into [Marblehead]76-marblehead with [their]2271-some of the active 's folks own tale to tell , sayin ' how [Ireson]327-ireson had shamed [[his]327-ireson town]2274-his town , an ' so forth an ' so on , an ' [[Ireson]327-ireson 's men]2275-ireson 's men [they]1868-the men was scared , seein ' public feelin ' agin ' 'em , an ' [they]1868-the men went back on [Ireson]327-ireson , an ' swore [he]327-ireson was respons'ble for the hull act . ' Tweren't [the women]2276-the women neither that tarred and feathered [him]327-ireson - [[Marblehead]76-marblehead [women]2278-women]2277-marblehead women do n't act that way - ' twas a passel o ' [men]2279-men an ' [boys]2074-boys , an ' [they]1868-the men carted [him]327-ireson araound [town]2281-town in an old dory till the bottom fell aout , and [Ireson]327-ireson [he]327-ireson told ['em]2282-'em [they]1868-the men 'd be sorry for it some day . Well , the facts come aout later , same 's [they]1868-the men usually do , too late to be any ways useful to [an honest man]2283-an honest man ; an ' Whittier [he]327-ireson come along an ' picked up the slack eend of a lyin ' tale , an ' tarred and feathered [Ben Ireson]327-ireson all over onct more after [he]327-ireson was dead . ' Twas the only tune [Whittier]328-whittier ever slipped up , an ' ' tweren't fair . [I]273-long jack whaled [Dan]260-dan good when [he]260-dan brought that piece back from [school]2284-school . Next ! "[273-long jack] [Harvey]250-harvey had never heard [Disko]263-disko talk so long , and collapsed with burning cheeks ; but , as [Dan]260-dan said promptly , [a boy]2079-a boy could only learn what [he]2079-a boy was taught at [school]2284-school , and life was too short to keep track of every lie along [the coast]859-the coast . Then [Manuel]272-manuel touched the jangling , jarring little machette to a queer tune , and sang something in Portuguese about " [Nina]329-nina , innocente ! "[272-manuel] ending with a full - handed sweep that brought the song up with a jerk . Then [Disko]263-disko obliged with [his]263-disko second song , to an old - fashioned creaky tune , and all joined in the chorus . This is one stanza : " Now [Aprile]330-aprile is over and melted the snow , And outer Noo Bedford [we]2289-we shortly must tow ; Yes , out o ' [Noo Bedford]77-noo bedford [we]2289-we shortly must clear , [We]2289-we 're the whalers that never see wheat in the ear . "[263-disko] Here the fiddle went very softly for a while by itself , and then : " Wheat - in - the - ear , [[my]628-the cook true - love]2290-my true - love 's posy blowin , Wheat - in - the - ear , [we]2289-we 're goin' off to [sea]2042-sea ; Wheat - in - the - ear , [I]628-the cook left [you]250-harvey fit for sowin , When [I]628-the cook come back a loaf o ' bread [you]250-harvey 'll be ! "[628-the cook] That made [Harvey]250-harvey almost weep , though [he]250-harvey could not tell why . But it was much worse when [the cook]628-the cook dropped the potatoes and held out [his]628-the cook hands for the fiddle . Still leaning against the locker door , [he]628-the cook struck into a tune that was like something very bad but sure to happen whatever [you]861-you did . After a little [he]628-the cook sang , in an unknown tongue , [his]628-the cook big chin down on the fiddle - tail , [his]628-the cook white eyeballs glaring in the lamplight . [Harvey]250-harvey swung out of [his]250-harvey bunk to hear better ; and amid the straining of the timbers and the wash of the waters the tune crooned and moaned on , like lee surf in a blind fog , till it ended with a wail . " [Jimmy Christmas]331-jimmy christmas ! Thet gives [me]260-dan the blue creevles , "[260-dan] said [Dan]260-dan . " What in thunder is it ? " It 's blown clear , "[263-disko] [Disko]263-disko cried , and [all the foc'sle]871-all the foc'sle tumbled up for a bit of fresh air . The fog had gone , but [a sullen sea]872-a sullen sea ran in great rollers behind [it]873-it . The ' [We]874-they 're Here ' slid , as it were , into long , sunk avenues and ditches which felt quite sheltered and homelike if [they]874-they would only stay still ; but [they]874-they changed without rest or mercy , and flung up [the schooner]553-the schooner to crown [one peak of a thousand gray hills]876-one peak of a thousand gray hills , while the wind hooted through [her]553-the schooner rigging as [she]553-the schooner zigzagged down [the slopes]877-the slopes . Far away [a sea]878-a sea would burst into a sheet of foam , and [the others]620-the others would follow suit as at a signal , till [Harvey]250-harvey 's eyes swam with the vision of interlacing whites and grays . Four or five [Mother Carey]286-mother 's chickens stormed round in circles , shrieking as [they]880-they swept past the bows . A rain - squall or two strayed aimlessly over the hopeless waste , ran down ' wind and back again , and melted away . " Seems to [me]276-uncle salters [I]276-uncle salters saw somethin' flicker jest naow over yonder , "[276-uncle salters] said [Uncle Salters]276-uncle salters , pointing to the northeast . " Ca n't be any of [the fleet]2092-the fleet , "[263-disko] said [Disko]263-disko , peering under [his]263-disko eyebrows , a hand on the foc'sle gangway as the solid bows hatcheted into the troughs . " [Sea]80-sea 's oilin ' over dretful fast . [Danny]260-dan , do n't [you]260-dan want to skip up a piece an ' see how aour trawl - buoy lays ? "[260-dan] [Danny]260-dan , in [his]260-dan big boots , trotted rather than climbed up the main rigging this consumed [Harvey]250-harvey with envy , hitched [himself]260-dan around the reeling cross - trees , and let [his]260-dan eye rove till it caught the tiny black buoy - flag on the shoulder of a mile - away swell . " [She]2324-she 's all right , "[260-dan] [he]260-dan hailed . " Sail O ! Dead to [the no'th'ard]2325-the no'th'ard , corain ' down like smoke ! Schooner [she]2324-she be , too . ' "[260-dan] [They]881-they waited yet another half - hour , the sky clearing in patches , with a flicker of sickly sun from time to time that made patches of olive - green water . Then a stump - foremast lifted , ducked , and disappeared , to be followed on the next wave by [a high stern with old - fashioned wooden snail's - horn davits]882-a high stern with old - fashioned wooden snail's - horn davits .
